cta_structure.title: Tibetan Supreme Justice Commission (TSJC)
cta_structure.short_description: The highest judicial authority of the Central Tibetan Administration, responsible for upholding the rule of law and ensuring justice.
cta_structure.long_description: The Tibetan Supreme Justice Commission (TSJC) is the highest judicial authority of the Central Tibetan Administration. It is responsible for upholding the rule of law, interpreting Tibetan laws, and ensuring justice within the Tibetan exile community. Functioning independently from the executive (Kashag) and legislative (Parliament) branches, the TSJC safeguards judicial independence and ensures that legal processes remain fair, impartial, and consistent with democratic principles and Tibetan values.

subsections.title: Justice Secretariat
subsections.content: The Justice Secretariat serves as the administrative and operational backbone of the TSJC. It supports the Commission by managing case documentation, coordinating hearings, maintaining judicial records, and facilitating communication between different justice bodies under the Tibetan judicial system. The Secretariat ensures the smooth functioning of the courts and assists in implementing judicial decisions.

subsections.title: Tibetan Circuit Justice Commission (TCJC)
subsections.content: The TCJC operates as a mobile judicial body under the TSJC. Its primary role is to bring justice closer to Tibetan communities by conducting hearings directly in settlements and regions that are geographically distant from the central judiciary. This system ensures access to justice for all Tibetans in exile, regardless of location, and helps resolve civil disputes in a timely and accessible manner.

details.title: TCJC – Dekyiling
details.content: Functions as a regional base for circuit justice activities in North India, conducting hearings for nearby settlements, reducing travel for litigants.

subsections.title: Tibetan Local Justice Commission (TLJC)
subsections.content: Handles minor civil disputes, mediation, and community-level legal matters. Emphasizing reconciliation and amicable settlement, the TLJC plays an important role in maintaining harmony within Tibetan communities by resolving conflicts at the grassroots level.

details.title: Northern Region (Dekyiling)
details.content: Serves Tibetan settlements across North India, providing accessible justice and mediation services within the community.

details.title: Southern Region (Bylakuppe)
details.content: Caters to one of the largest Tibetan settlement areas in South India, resolving community disputes and maintaining social harmony.

details.title: Ladakh Region
details.content: Serves Tibetan communities in Ladakh, addressing local justice needs while considering the unique high-altitude context.

cta_structure.title: Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile (TPiE)
cta_structure.short_description: The unicameral legislative body and highest representative institution representing Tibetans globally.
cta_structure.long_description:
The Tibetan Parliament-in Exile (TPiE) is the unicameral legislative body and highest representative institution of the Central Tibetan Administration (CTA)—the democratically elected government of Tibetans living in exile. It embodies the democratic aspirations of the global Tibetan community and functions as a central pillar of Tibetan governance alongside the Judiciary and Executive.

Established as part of the democratic structures developed by His Holiness the 14th Dalai Lama, the Tibetan Parliament in Exile evolved from early representative bodies into a fully modern legislature. Democratic governance in exile began soon after the Tibetan government was reconstituted in India following the 1959 uprising and subsequent exile, with formal legislative powers progressively strengthened through the Charter of the Tibetans in Exile.

subsections.title: Location and Significance
subsections.content: The Parliament sits in Dharamshala, India, in the foothills of the Himalayas, a place often referred to as 'Little Lhasa'. Its position in exile underscores both the ongoing Tibetan struggle for freedom and the resilience of its democratic institutions.

subsections.title: Composition and Representation
subsections.content: The 17th Tibetan Parliament in Exile comprises 45 members from across the Tibetan diaspora. Representatives include ten members each from the three traditional provinces of Tibet (Ü-Tsang, Kham, and Amdo), members from the four major schools of Tibetan Buddhism and the Bon religion, and representatives of Tibetans living in North America, Europe, Australasia, and other regions. This structure ensures both cultural diversity and geographic representation within the legislature.

subsections.title: Leadership and Electoral Process
subsections.content: Parliamentarians elect among themselves a Speaker and Deputy Speaker to preside over sessions. Elections are held every five years, with all Tibetans in exile aged 18 and above eligible to vote and those aged 25 and above eligible to contest. Sessions are typically convened bi-annually.

subsections.title: Functions and Role
subsections.content: The TPiE has several key responsibilities within the Central Tibetan Administration:

details.title: Legislative Authority
details.content: To enact laws, frame rules and regulations, and amend policies in accordance with the Charter of the Tibetans in Exile.

details.title: Oversight
details.content: To supervise the administration's finances and public expenditure.

details.title: Advocacy and Liaison
details.content: To engage with governments, parliaments, NGOs and civil society worldwide to garner support for the Tibetan cause and international advocacy.

details.title: Representation
details.content: To bring the concerns and aspirations of the global Tibetan diaspora into policy debates at the highest level.

subsections.title: Democratic Resilience & Engagement
subsections.content: Despite operating in exile, the Tibetan Parliament continues to uphold democratic norms and processes, reflecting the enduring commitment of the Tibetan people to self-governance, freedom, and non-violent advocacy. Its activities extend beyond law-making to include cultural preservation, community outreach, and international diplomacy.

subsections.title: Parliamentary Secretariat
subsections.content: The Parliament Secretariat is the administrative and operational backbone of the TPiE, responsible for ensuring the smooth functioning, continuity, and institutional integrity of the Parliament. While the MPs serve as elected representatives, the Secretariat provides the professional, non-partisan support that enables Parliament to discharge its constitutional and democratic responsibilities effectively.

details.title: Role and Mandate
details.content: Functions as the permanent administrative body of the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, assisting in its legislative, oversight, and representative functions in accordance with the Charter.

details.title: Legislative Support
details.content: Organizes parliamentary sessions, prepares agendas, records proceedings, and maintains official transcripts and resolutions.

details.title: Documentation
details.content: Maintains laws passed, debates, and archival records, serving as the democratic memory of the Tibetan people in exile.

details.title: Liaison
details.content: Acts as a bridge between MPs, CTA departments, and external stakeholders, coordinating delegations and international outreach.

details.title: Structure
details.content: Operates under the Speaker, headed by a Secretary-level official and staffed by neutral, professional civil servants.

subsections.title: Local Tibetan Assemblies (40 Locations)
subsections.content: Grassroots democratic institutions functioning as the local representative bodies of the Tibetan people in exile, ensuring democratic participation extends beyond Dharamshala to settlements across India.

subsections.title: Freedom Movement Sub-Committees (BRDL)
subsections.content: Functioning globally in 148 locations, these committees mobilize Tibetans and supporters for advocacy, awareness, and democratic engagement. They also support the grassroots collection of the Tibetan Chatrel contributions.

cta_structure.title: Kashag (Cabinet)
cta_structure.short_description: The executive branch of the CTA, headed by the Sikyong, responsible for daily governance and administration.
cta_structure.long_description: The Kashag is the executive branch of the Central Tibetan Administration, responsible for day-to-day governance. It is headed by the Sikyong (Political Leader), who is democratically elected for a five-year term. The Kashag consists of seven Kalons (Cabinet Ministers) nominated by the Sikyong and approved by the Parliament. It functions collectively, with decisions taken through consultation and shared responsibility, and is accountable to the Parliament through established checks and balances.

departments.title: Department of Religion and Culture
departments.content: Primary responsibility is to preserve, protect, and promote Tibetan religion, culture, language, and identity in exile. Adapts traditions to contemporary global contexts while providing policy guidance for religious institutions.

subsections.title: Monasteries (259)
subsections.content: Oversees and supports spiritual, educational, and cultural centers for the Tibetan community.

subsections.title: Nunneries (36)
subsections.content: Dedicated to the religious education, spiritual development, and empowerment of Tibetan nuns.

subsections.title: Cultural Institutions
subsections.content: Supports TIPA (Performing Arts), Tibet House Society, CUTS (Higher Education), LTWA (Library & Archives), Norbulingka Institute (Arts & Crafts), and Manjushree Center.

departments.title: Department of Home
departments.content: Responsible for the administration, welfare, rehabilitation, and socio-economic development of Tibetan communities in exile. Acts as the primary ground-level link through its network of Settlement Offices.

subsections.title: Settlement Offices (TSO)
subsections.content: Oversees 44 TSOs (36 in India, 7 in Nepal, 1 in Bhutan) functioning as local administrative units.

subsections.title: Agricultural & Welfare
subsections.content: Supports farming-based livelihoods and focuses on social protection and community well-being.

subsections.title: Real Estate & Housing
subsections.content: Manages land, housing, and property-related matters within settlements.

subsections.title: Community Care
subsections.content: Oversees Old Age Homes for the elderly and Baby Crèches for early childhood care.

departments.title: Department of Finance
departments.content: Responsible for managing financial administration, revenue systems, budgeting, and development financing of the CTA. Ensures financial sustainability and transparency.

subsections.title: Green Book & Chatrel
subsections.content: Manages official civic records (Green Book) and the voluntary community contribution system (Chatrel).

subsections.title: SARD & GDF
subsections.content: Social and Resource Development Fund mobilizes resources, while Gangjong Development Finance supports entrepreneurship.

subsections.title: Tech & Engagement
subsections.content: Includes TCRC (Digital Capacity), Tibet Corps (Youth Volunteerism), and the Blue Book for global supporters.

subsections.title: Women Empowerment Desk
subsections.content: Works to strengthen the economic and institutional participation of Tibetan women.

departments.title: Department of Education
departments.content: Responsible for the overall education system, ensuring quality education that balances modern knowledge with Tibetan language, culture, and values.

subsections.title: Academic Sections
subsections.content: Divided into Traditional (Language, History, Philosophy) and Modern (Science, Math, Vocational) sections.

subsections.title: Scholarship & Council
subsections.content: Administers assistance programs for higher education and coordinates policy through the Education Council.

subsections.title: Support Services
subsections.content: Provides academic and psychosocial Guidance via the Counselling Section and standardizes Terminology for modern subjects.

departments.title: Department of Security
departments.content: Responsible for community security, refugee reception, legal documentation, and ensuring the security of His Holiness the Dalai Lama.

subsections.title: Reception Centers
subsections.content: Operates first points of contact in Kathmandu, Delhi, and Dharamshala for newly arrived Tibetans from Tibet.

subsections.title: Documentation Support
subsections.content: Assists with legal identity and travel docs, including Registration Certificates (RC) and Identity Certificates (IC).

subsections.title: Administration
subsections.content: Manages internal security-related procedures and departmental records.

departments.title: Department of Information and International Relations (DIIR)
departments.content: The voice of the Tibetan people, responsible for public information, media engagement, international advocacy, and diplomacy.

subsections.title: Information & News
subsections.content: Produces news via Tibet News Bureau, Sheja, Tibetan Freedom, and the official CTA website. Includes the China Desk.

subsections.title: International Relations
subsections.content: Oversees 13 Offices of Tibet (including Washington DC, Geneva, London) and desks for UN, EU, and HR.

subsections.title: Audiovisual & Museum
subsections.content: Supports Tibet TV (AV outreach) and the Tibet Museum (educational and historical documentation).

subsections.title: Research & Publishing
subsections.content: Contains Narthang Press (publishing arm) and Tibet Policy Institute (TPI - core think tank).

departments.title: Department of Health
departments.content: Responsible for safeguarding physical and mental health. Plans, coordinates, and oversees services across settlements in India, Nepal, and Bhutan.

subsections.title: Hospitals & Clinics
subsections.content: Manages a network of 12 hospitals/PHCs, 33 clinics, and mobile units for remote areas.

subsections.title: Affiliated Orgs
subsections.content: Coordinates with Delek Hospital, Men-Tsee-Khang (Traditional Medicine), and Ngoenga School.

subsections.title: Sports & Well-being
subsections.content: Includes the Tibetan National Sports Association (TNSA) to promote sports and healthy lifestyles.

cta_structure.title: Autonomous Bodies
cta_structure.short_description: Independent institutions ensuring democratic integrity and accountability within the CTA.
cta_structure.long_description: Autonomous Bodies are constitutionally independent institutions functioning separately from the executive branch. Their heads are elected by the Parliament to ensure non-partisan staffing and financial transparency, serving as core pillars of Tibetan democracy in exile.

subsections.title: Election Commission
subsections.content: Responsible for conducting free, fair, and transparent elections for the Sikyong, Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, and Local Assemblies.

subsections.title: Public Service Commission (PSC)
subsections.content: Responsible for merit-based recruitment, examination, and appointment of civil servants within the CTA, ensuring institutional efficiency.

subsections.title: Office of the Auditor General
subsections.content: The highest financial oversight authority, auditing accounts and ensuring transparency across all CTA departments and affiliated institutions.
